metadata.title: Recent update on COVID-19 in India: Is locking down the country enough?

abstract.text: India is the second-largest population in the world, and developing nation, it is not well equipped 25 as compared to other developed countries like China, USA, Italy, Germany. Hitherto, in the 26 scenario of the global pandemic, SARS-CoV-2 affected a hundred thousand people in 202 27 countries and territories, which could impart a devastating impact on the Indian population. In 28 the absence of vaccines, the only way to respond against this critical condition is by practicing 29 large-scale social distancing. Interestingly, China diminishes COVID-19 cases by forcefully 30 applying strict restrictions to isolate even mild symptomatic individuals; local authorities went 31 door to door for testing, increases the hospital facilities, including ventilators. Likewise, India 32 also took a very bold decision to lock down the whole country for 21 days, starting from 24 33 March 2020 after detecting 571 positive COVID-19 confirmed cases. However, till 1 April 2020, 34 SARS-CoV-2 positive cases were growing exponentially, which raises the concerns if the 35 number of reported and actual cases are similar. Our analysis suggests that there is an urgent 36 need to take action to extend the period of lockdown and allocate enough resources, including 37 personnel, beds, and intensive care facilities, to manage the situation in the next few days and 38 weeks. Otherwise, the outbreak in India can reach the level of the USA or Italy or could be worse 39 than these countries within a few days or weeks, given the size of the population and lack of 40 resources.

On April 2, India reported 2,586 confirmed COVID-19 cases followed by 73 54 deaths according to the http://gis.ndma.gov.in/arcgis/apps/sites/#/data and 55 https://www.covid19india.org/ (4, 5). The number of confirmed cases seems less compared to 56 other countries. However, taking into account the 1.3 billion population of India, it was 57 necessary to take strict and essential measures as soon as possible. Within days of the epidemic, 58 the Indian government ordered schools closure, religious events with large gatherings were either 59 canceled or postponed. The local authorities encouraged residents to minimize the travel, avoid 60 crowded places, and promoted physical distancing, travel restrictions imposed between states 61 and cities, undoubtedly played a significant role in reducing the exposure and delayed the onset 62 of the outbreak in several towns and villages in India.

Another major issue in India is more than half of the population lives on 87 daily wages who require the basic need of living that includes food and shelter. Extending the 88 lockdown period will have a significant impact on such vulnerable populations in the country.

On 24 March 2020, the Indian government has a republic, secular, multi-religious country, it is difficult to impose the lockdown163 overnight without proper awareness and announcements. Because of incomplete public 164 understanding, lockdown did not serve the purpose properly and made religious places a hotspot 165 for COVID-19 cases. In early March 2020, around 2,000 Muslim devotees, including visitors 166 from Indonesia and Malaysia, started gathering at Tabligh-e-Jamaat's Markaz in New Delhi 167 without proper precautions and sanitation practices, lack of social distancing for several days 168 (11). Before the applicability of complete India lockdown, half of the peoples were spread across 169 India without medical surveillance. Recent reports suggesting that several people attended the 170 gathering found positive for COVID-19 and unknowingly spread the disease in different regions 171 of India. The above mentioned is just one of the incidents reported, several other religious events 172 are still ongoing even after the curfew and complete lockdown raising doubts about the total 173 number of COVID-19 cases reported till date. Therefore, Government and local authorities need 174 to take further strict actions and appropriately observe religious events and large gatherings 175 beforehand to stop the uncontrollable spread of COVID-19. Further, it is essential to focus on 176 measures like self-isolation, social distancing, testing all of the suspected cases, and increase the 177 hospital facilities to treat COVID-19 patients as much as possible.

FIGREF12.text: The COVID-19 outbreak in India is relatively new compared to other countries, 230 proper surveillance, transparent reporting of characteristics of infected individuals is necessary to 231 update regularly. Nevertheless, aggressive steps need to be taken with critically ill SARS-CoV-2 232 infected patients, including isolation and ventilatory support. Our findings represent further 233 lockdown restrictions that need to be extended urgently, in a matter of days. To tackle the 234 substantial number of unnecessary deaths, we need to focus on increasing the testing capacity 235 and speed up the rate of recovery of infected people by providing all the necessary support and 236 medication. For individuals with other comorbidities or older people requires regular testing, 237 more robust personal protection and should have access to intensive surveillance or therapy.
